senses.sense: (obsolete) A pneumatometer.
Relating to pneudraulics.
(music) A neume.
The spirit or soul.
(Gnosticism) One of three levels of a human being, the spirit, along with the body and soul.
plural of pneuma
Of, relating to, or resembling air or other gases
Of or relating to pneumatics
Powered by, or filled with, compressed air
(zoology) Having cavities filled with air
Spiritual; of or relating to the pneuma
(of a woman) well-rounded; full-breasted; bouncy
(dated) A vehicle, such as a bicycle, whose wheels are fitted with pneumatic tyres.
(gnosticism) In the gnostic theologian Valentinus' triadic grouping of man, the highest type; a person focused on spiritual reality (the other two being hylic and psychic).
pneumatic
In a pneumatic manner.
Using pneumatics.
(biology) The state of being pneumatic, or of having a cavity or cavities filled with air.
examples: the pneumaticity of the bones of birds

senses.sense: The branch of mechanics that deals with the mechanical properties of gases
(theology, obsolete) The scientific study or knowledge of spiritual beings and their relations to God, angels, and human beings.
spiritualism centred on the belief in the pneuma
To fill with air cavities.
Having air cavities.
(medicine) A hernia or air-filled cyst within the lung.
(medicine) A gaseous swelling, especially within the scrotum.
(marine biology) A sac or other structure containing air and used for flotation by a marine organism, chiefly used in reference to those of kelps and siphonophores.
(botany, histology) A group of cells with spiral secondary wall thickenings, present in a velamen; acts as an airway for gas exchange for respiration or photosynthesis
(botany, histology) A group of cells presumed to be specialised as an airway for ventilation of particular tissues.
(physiology) A tracing of the respiratory movements, obtained by a pneumatograph or stethograph.
An instrument for recording the movements of the thorax or chest wall during respiration.
Alternative form of pneumatological
Of or pertaining to pneumatology.
One versed in pneumatology.
The study of spiritual beings and phenomena, especially the interactions between humans and God.
(Christianity, theology) The study of the Holy Spirit as revealed in Scripture.
The science dealing with air or gases, their physical and chemical properties, therapeutic applications, etc.
(geology) the alteration of rocks and minerals by gases or magmatic fluid within volcanos etc
(geology) Relating to pneumatolysis
A device used to measure the force of inspiration or expiration of a person's lungs.
spirometry
(zoology) A gas-filled sac or float of some colonial marine coelenterates, such as the Portuguese man-of-war.
(botany) An aerial root, in mangroves etc., specialized for gaseous exchange.
An apparatus consisting of a bag with a tube and mouthpiece, which may be attached to the body. The bag contains oxygen to be breathed by the wearer in rescue work in mines, etc.
(medicine) the abnormal accumulation of air or other gas in the body.
(medicine) The presence of undissolved gases in the urine during urination.
Alternative form of neume
plural of pneumectomy
Synonym of pneumonectomy
(surgery) centesis of a lung, typically to remove fluid
Of, pertaining to or caused by a pneumococcus bacterium
plural of pneumococcus
Of, pertaining to or caused by a pneumococcus bacterium.
A gram-positive bacterium, Streptococcus pneumoniae, that causes pneumonia and other infectious diseases
(disease) A disease of the lungs caused by inhalation of particulate matter.
An image produced by means of pneumoencephalography.
(anatomy) Of or pertaining to the lungs and the stomach
(anatomy) vagus (attributive)

(anatomy) The pneumogastric nerve; one of the tenth pair of cranial nerves which are distributed to the pharynx, esophagus, larynx, lungs, heart, stomach, liver, and spleen, and, in fishes and many amphibia, to the branchial apparatus and also to the sides of the body.
(medicine) A record (often overnight) of the respiratory movements of a subject by the use of pneumography.
Alternative form of pneumatograph
Relating to pneumography.
scientific description of the lungs.
hemopneumothorax
Relating to pulmonology.
The study of the respiratory system and organs.
Synonym of pneumonolysis
pneumatic massage of the internal portions of the ear
A spirometer.
plural of pneumonectomy
The surgical removal of all or part of a lung.
An acute or chronic inflammation of the lungs caused by viruses, bacteria or other microorganisms, or sometimes by physical or chemical irritants.
Of, or relating to the lungs; pulmonary.
Of, or relating to pneumonia.
One who has pneumonia.
A medicine to treat lung disease.
(medicine) Of, pertaining to, or suffering from, pneumonitis.
(pathology) Inflammation of the tissue of the lungs.
Alternative spelling of pneumoconiosis
The separation of an adherent lung from the pleura, to permit collapse of the lung. It was formerly used to treat tuberculosis.
A spirometer; a pneumometer.
(pathology) Any disease of the lungs
(surgery) The surgical procedure of making an incision in the lung.
Archaic form of pneumonia.
(medicine) The presence of air in the pericardial cavity.
The presence of air or gas in the peritoneal cavity.
(surgery) fixation of layers of the lung tissue
(medicine) Hemorrhage of the lungs.
The use of pneumotherapy.
(medicine) The treatment of disease by inhalations of compressed or rarefied air.
(medicine) Presence of air inside the pleural cavity, usually caused by injury either to the lung or the chest wall.
(dated) Synonym of pneumonectomy
Any pneumotoxic substance.
Having an affinity for (or moving towards) the tissues of the lungs
The condition of being pneumotropic
typhous pneumonia
ventriculography of the ventricles of the larynx
